items.author: Kirk Honeycutt
items.content: Pixar again hitches top-notch storytelling to the very best in CG animation.
The sleek beauty, crafty wit, family warmth, and impeccable slapstick suffusing The Incredibles immediately vaults it to a new, higher level of entertainment.

items.author: Todd McCarthy
items.content: As deliriously smart escapist fare, The Incredibles is practically nonpareil.

items.author: David Chute
items.content: The Incredibles creates so seamless a mood of exhilaration that we resent being pulled out of it.

items.author: Richard Corliss
items.content: The Incredibles has those characters, that heart.
The vocal performances are a blast, Hunter's and Lee's in particular. The animation of the villain's tropical isle is stunning.

items.author: Robert Wilonsky
items.content: Yes, yes--The Incredibles is beautiful to look at, but even more lovely beneath the computer-generated surfaces.

items.author: Scott Tobias
items.content: The action sequences are choreographed with the crackerjack timing expected from Pixar, but the film's funniest and most affecting moments exploit the tension between a special family and a world that insists on dulling them down.

items.author: Jessica Winter
items.content: Unfortunately, the delicious snatches of reflexive wit function as mere intermissions between the distended action sequences and Michael BayÂ–style megatonnage, which have earned Pixar its first ever PG rating.
